collaborations.description: The name(s) of the collaboration(s) of the author(s) (e.g. CIELO or n\_TOF)
collaborations.name: collaborations

evaluationDate.description: The date this evaluation was performed
evaluationDate.name: evaluationDate

cutoffDate.description: Only experimental data before this date are considered in this evaluation
cutoffDate.name: cutoffDate

acceptanceDate.description: The date this evaluation was accepted into a library
acceptanceDate.name: acceptanceDate

acknowledgements.description: Statements acknowledging contributions of some other sort (e.g. funding) not otherwise covered here
acknowledgements.name: acknowledgements

version.description: Version of the current evaluation or document, using whatever scheme is appropriate for the library to which the (partial) evaluation belongs
version.name: version

keywords.description: A collection of NSR, PACS or PhySH keywords associated with this evaluation
keywords.name: keywords

body.description: The main body of text describing the evaluation.  For translated ENDF-6 data, the entire MF1/MT451 text goes here.
body.name: body

computerCodes.description: The list of programs used to perform this evaluation
computerCodes.name: computerCodes

experimentalDataSets.description: List of references to the experimental data sets used and any corrections/rescalings used in the evaluation process
experimentalDataSets.name: experimentalDataSets

bibliography.description: The list of references used in the evaluation documentation
bibliography.name: bibliography

endfCompatible.description: Documentation restricted to plain ascii with 66 characters per line, for backwards compatibility with ENDF-6.
endfCompatible.name: endfCompatible

author.description: Each author has their own \element{author} node providing contact information, etc.
author.name: author

label.description: Label node to assist in linking to this list item.
label.name: label

note.description: Any special note pertaining to the author
note.name: note

description: The name of the author; use \attr{encoding}=\attrval{utf-8}
\attr{markup}=\attrval{latex} if needed.
text.name: text

description: The email address of the author.  Unlike the \element{name}, \element{affiliation} and \element{collaboration} elements, email does not require the optional unicode encoding.  However we use the \element{text} node here for consistency.
text.name: text

affiliation.description: Each affiliation is described in an \element{affiliation} element.
affiliation.name: affilation

label.description: Label node to assist in linking to this list item.
label.name: label

description: Author affiliation to either an institution or collaboration; use \attr{encoding}=\attrval{utf-8}
or \attr{markup}=\attrval{latex} if needed.
text.name: text

description: Note pertaining to this author.
text.name: text

description: Each collaboration is listed in the \element{collaboration} element.
collaboration.name: collaboration

label.description: Label node to assist in linking to this list item.
label.name: label

description: Hyperlink to the collaboration web page.
link.name: link

text.description: The collaboration name, may be in unicode or use alternative markups.
text.name: text

description: The title may be plain ascii text (\attr{encoding}=\attrval{ascii}),
use more complex encoding (\attr{encoding}=\attrval{utf-8}) or may be written
in a markup language like \LaTeX\ (\attr{markup}=\attrval{latex}) or HTML
(\attr{markup}=\attrval{html}). %; please keep the title to one line.
text.name: text

title.description: Use this markup to provide the title of the evaluation/document.
title.name: title

description: The abstract may be plain ascii text (\attr{encoding}=\attrval{ascii}), use more complex encoding
(\attr{encoding}=\attrval{utf-8}) or may be written in a markup language like \LaTeX\
(\attr{markup}=\attrval{latex}) or HTML (\attr{markup}=\attrval{html}).
%; please keep the abstract to at most one page, but preferably one paragraph.
text.name: text

abstract.description: If needed, use this markup to provide a short summary of the documentation.
abstract.name: abstract

description: The body may be plain ascii text (\attr{encoding}=\attrval{ascii}), use more complex encoding
(\attr{encoding}=\attrval{utf-8}) or may be written in a markup language like \LaTeX\
(\attr{markup}=\attrval{latex}) or HTML (\attr{markup}=\attrval{html}).
text.name: text

body.description: Use this markup for the main text of the documentation.  An ENDF-6's entire MF1/MT451 file is equivalent to this element.
body.name: body

description: The URL to which the DOI refers
link.name: link

text.description: The actual DOI identifier; this should be plain ascii encoding and plain text markup
text.name: text

description: The Digital Object Identifier (DOI) is a unique identifier affixed to a document or dataset \cite{doi}.
A DOI is a character string that uniquely identifies a piece of information and is associated with the URL
where the information may be found.
doi.name: doi

description: A link to the text of the copyright statement
link.name: link

text.description: The text of the copyright statement
text.name: text

copyright.description: The \element{copyright} element provides a way for evaluators to add or link to a copyright statement for the (partial) evaluation.
copyright.name: copyright

description: The evaluation date in ISO-8601 format \cite{datetime} using the \element{date} markup from Ref.~\cite{GPDCs}.
date.name: date

description: This markup provides a space for the evaluators to date when the evaluation and documentation were complete.
This date is assigned by the evaluation authors/evaluators.  This date is equivalent to ENDF-6's EDATE.
evaluationDate.name: evaluationDate

description: The evaluation date in ISO-8601 format \cite{datetime} using the \element{date} markup from Ref.~\cite{GPDCs}.
date.name: date

description: This markup provides a space for the date when the evaluation was accepted into a particular library.
This date is assigned by each data project.  This date is equivalent to ENDF-6's DDATE.
acceptanceDate.name: acceptanceDate

description: The evaluation date in ISO-8601 format \cite{datetime} using the \element{date} markup from Ref.~\cite{GPDCs}.
date.name: date

description: The \element{cutoffDate} is used to state that no experimental data after the cutoff date
is used in the current evaluation.  This markup is equivalent to the ENSDF CUT field \cite{ensdf}.
This markup should not be used as a replacement for explicitly listing what data is used in the evaluation.
cutoffDate.name: cutoffDate

date.description: Revision date for this version stored in ISO-8601 format.
date.name: date

description: Used to state the version of a document or code using whatever markup is appropriate.
Usually versions are simple numbers (e.g. subversion revision numbers),
but they can be much more complex (MacOS Sierra for instance).  Given this, we use a
\element{text} low level container to store the version information itself.
When used at the \element{documentation} level, it refers to the version of the evaluation
and is thus equivalent to ENDF-6's NMOD/RDATE flags.
version.name: version

acknowledgement.description: Statement acknowledging contributions of some other sort (e.g. funding) not otherwise covered.
acknowledgement.name: acknowledgement

description: Statement acknowledging contributions of some other sort (e.g. funding) not otherwise covered.
text.name: text

description: This element allows one to acknowledge contributions of some other sort (e.g. funding) not otherwise covered.
All United States Department of Energy funded work require a statement of the funding used and this statement should be placed here.
acknowledgement.name: acknowledgement

description: Both the American Physical Society and the National Nuclear Data Center use keywording systems to categorize documents.
The \element{keywords} element allows us to collect these keywords together.
The National Nuclear Data Center uses the Nuclear Science References (NSR) keywording system.
The American Physical Society's Physics and Astronomy Classification Scheme (PACS) system is another keywording
system for categorizing documents.
The APS has stated that this keyword system is obsolete and will be replaced with the Physics Subject Headings (PhySH)
system~\cite{PhySH}.\footnote{For more information, see \url{https://journals.aps.org/PACS} and
\url{https://journals.aps.org/authors/physh}.}  We note that it is unlikely that older papers will be recoded or that
older papers will have their PACS codes removed.  Therefore we expect that the present markup will be relevant for
the forseeable future.
keywords.name: keywords

keyword.description: A NSR, PACS or PhySH keyword associated with this evaluation
keyword.name: keyword

keyword.description: A NSR, PACS or PhySH keyword associated with this evaluation
keyword.name: keyword

type.description: The name of the keywording scheme used, either "nsr", "pacs" or "physh"
type.name: type

text.description: A keyword. For computer readability, only ascii encoding with plain text markup shall be used.
text.name: text

computerCode.description: Each set of code and inputs has a \element{computerCode} node.
computerCode.name: computerCode

computerCodes.description: Lists the programs used while preparing the evaluation, along with code inputs.
computerCodes.name: computerCodes

label.description: Label node to assist in linking to this list item.
label.name: label

description: The name of the code, using all the same restrictions, etc. as the \hyperlink{sec:name}{\element{name}} markup introduced above in the
\hyperlink{sec:author}{\element{author}} markup.  This includes allowing unicode program names (such as CEA's GALILE\'E processing code \cite{galilee}).
name.name: name

description: The version of the code, with all the restrictions and allowances of the \hyperlink{sec:version}{\element{version}} markup introduced above.
version.name: version

description: The command line arguments used when invoking this code.
executionArguments.name: executionArguments

description: Information for accessing the source code repository for this program.
codeRepo.name: codeRepo

description: Any note describing extra information needed to run the code in the manner needed to reproduce the evaluation.
note.name: note

description: The list of inputs for the code used.
inputDecks.name: inputDecks

computerCode.description: Contains the information pertaining to a code used in the evaluation process and the inputs for that code.
computerCode.name: computerCode

label.description: A name or label referring to this code repository.
label.name: label

href.description: Hyperlink to the source code repository.
href.name: href

revisionID.description: Revision identifier. Could be a tag, svn revision number or git commit hash for example.
revisionID.name: revisionID

description: The \element{codeRepo} element provides a mechanism for referencing the exact version of a computer code used in the evaluation.
This markup is meant to point to the exact revision of a code in a generally available code repository.
codeRepo.name: codeRepo

inputDecks.description: Lists the inputs for a given code.
inputDecks.name: inputDecks

label.description: A name or label to refer to this input deck.
label.name: label

filename.description: File name (possibly including relative path) for this input deck.
filename.name: filename

text.description: The actual text in the input file for the code used.  If the input uses a structured format such as XML, escape it with CDATA tags.
text.name: text

inputDeck.description: The \element{inputDeck} contains the actual code inputs.  The name of the element was chosen to avoid any confusion with other uses of the word ``input'' while evoking the mental image of a stack of punch cards such as used in the early days of nuclear data.
inputDeck.name: inputDeck

description: Details for invoking this code.
text.name: text

executionArguments.description: Use this markup to list any special command line specifics used to invoke this code.
executionArguments.name: executionArguments

exforDataSet.description: One for each EXFOR data set.
exforDataSet.name: exforDataSet

description: Container for experimental data sets.  Currently only EXFOR data set child elements (\element{exforDataSet}) are defined.
This top-level tag is so-named so that other child elements can be added, say for XUNDL datasets or for simple tables of XYdY pairs for raw experimental data,
without distorting the meaning of the top-level tag.
experimentalDataSets.name: experimentalDataSets

entry.description: The EXFOR `ENTRY' identifier (a 5 character ascii string).
entry.name: entry

description: The EXFOR `SUBENT' (subentry) is an 3 character ascii string comprised of integers only.
Each subentry corresponds to a unique dataset within the experiment detailed in the EXFOR entry.
The subentry labeled `001' is the documentation subentry for that EXFOR entry and should not be referred to here.
subentry.name: subentry

label.description: Label node to assist in linking to this list item.
label.name: label

retrievalDate.description: The date the EXFOR subentry was retrieved.
retrievalDate.name: retrievalDate

covarianceScript.description: The script describing the generation of covariance data..
covarianceScript.name: covarianceScript

correctionScript.description: The script describing any modifications to the data.
correctionScript.name: correctionScript

description: Contains a reference to a specific EXFOR subentry (specified with the \attr{SUBENT} attribute) and details of the retrieval and any corrections, rescalings, etc.
This markup does not contain the full EXFOR entry or subentry -- these are already stored in the master EXFOR database at the IAEA.  This markup provides a scheme to reference the datasets only.
We note that we only support the covariance generate scripts and correction scripts provided by V. Zerkin in his EXFOR Web application \cite{exforApp}.
Other schemes could be designed but for the present none have been enumerated.  If the current markup is insufficient to describe modifications/corrections to a data set,
the evaluator should consider documenting it in the main \element{body} element.
exforDataSet.name: exforDataSet

description: The date that an item was retrieved from the web, in ISO-8601 format \cite{datetime} using the \element{date} markup from Ref.~\cite{GPDCs}.
date.name: date

retrievalDate.description: The date that an item was retrieved from the web.  Currently only used within \element{exforDataSet} elements.
retrievalDate.name: retrievalDate

text.description: Covariance generation script. The syntax is XML, so it must use \attr{markup}=\attrval{XML} and be escaped with CDATA tags.
text.name: text

description: V. Zerkin's EXFOR retrieval web application \cite{exforApp} provides a mechanism for computing covariance matrices based off the statistical and systematic errors presented in an EXFOR entry.
This markup provides the means to place this script directly in the documentation for future reference and for reconstructing the covariance used at a later date.
covarianceScript.name: covarianceScript

text.description: Correction script text. Currently only plain text is supported.
text.name: text

description: V. Zerkin's EXFOR retrieval web application \cite{exforApp} provides a mechanism for rudimentary data correction of an EXFOR entry.
This markup provides the means to place this script directly in the documentation for future reference and for reconstructing the covariance used at a later date.
correctionScript.name: correctionScript

bibitem.description: Each entry in the bibliography has a unique \element{bibitem}.
bibitem.name: bibitem

description: The bibliography markup gives the evaluator the tools to provide references for this evaluation with a system as flexible as \LaTeX\ or as simple as plain text.
Our notation here is clearly inspired by \LaTeX\ and should be familiar to many scientists and engineers.  The \element{bibliography} element is the outer container
for all of the \element{bibitem}s (in keeping with \LaTeX\ notation).
bibliography.name: bibliography

description: The {\em unique} reference to this bibitem.  When using \LaTeX markup, it is natural to use this as the key used when cross referencing with \LaTeX's \verb+\cite{}+ command.
label.name: label

description: The text of the reference.  Allowed values of the \attr{markup} attribute are \attrval{ascii}, \attrval{bibtex}, \attrval{latex}, \attrval{bibtexml} and \attrval{openXML}.
text.name: text

description: The \element{bibitem} element contains the actual bibliographic reference.
The \attr{label} attribute provides the landing point for hyperreferences to a \element{bibitem} and must be unique.
bibitem.name: bibitem

text.description: Text content of ENDF-6 compatible documentation. Restricted to ASCII characters.
text.name: text

description: Documentation in ENDF-6 is stored in MF1 MT451. This section contains free-form text which cannot be
broken up into the various sections supported by the \element{documentation} node without manual intervention.
The \element{endfCompatible} node is provided to support backwards compatibility and translating back to ENDF-6.
This node is expected to eventually be deprecated, but in the meantime evaluators should consider providing a short
summary of the documentation in ENDF-6 compatible form.
endfCompatible.name: endfCompatible
